item.title: Chapter 1
item.description: Chapter 1 Exercise Solutions # Download Solutions Embdedded solutions: # Exercises for Chapter 1 of "Introduction to Programming using Python" # Solutions made by Skyler Vestal (Hook 'Em) # 1.2 print("Welcome to Python") print("Welcome to Python") print("Welcome to Python") print("Welcome to Python") print("Welcome to Python") # 1.4 print("a a^2 a^3") print("1 1 1") print("2 4 8") print("3 9 27") print("4 16 64") # 1.7 print(4 * (1 - (1 / 3) + (1 / 5) - (1 / 7) + (1 / 9) - (1 / 11))) print(4 * (1 - (1 / 3) + (1 / 5) - (1 / 7) + (1 / 9) - (1 / 11) + (1 / 13) - (1 / 15))) # 1.

item.title: Midterm
item.description: Midterm Review # MC/Short Answer Section # Noah’s Multiple Choice # Noah (fellow TA) has made a lot of great multiple choice questions that he’s decided to share with me. Big ğŸ‘ for him. Assume libraries have been imported correctly for the following questions. What is output by the following code? x = int(52.2) y = math.floor(999.9) print(x, y) A. 52 1000 B. 52 999 C.

item.title: Syntax
item.description: Python Syntax Review for CS 303E # Variables and Datatypes # Types of Data # # Integer datatype: Stores whole numbers like -32, 0, 66, 2332312, ... int_var = -54 # Float datatype: Stores decimal numbers like 3.0, -2.3232, .00033, # 5.6e+15 float_var = -.04 # Boolean datatype: Stores the value true or false bool_var = True bool_var = False # String datatype: Stores any word str_var = "You can use double quotes" str_var = 'or single quotes for strings' Modification # # These two are the same # This works for +, -, *, /, //, %, ** int_var = int_var + 5 int_var += 5 # Operators examples 10 / 3 # == 3.

item.title: Chapter 2
item.description: Chapter 2 Exercise Solutions # Download Solutions Embedded solutions: # Exercies for Chapter 2 of "Introduction to Programming using Python" # Solutions made by Skyler Vestal (Hook 'Em) # 2.1 celsius = eval(input("Enter a degree in Celsius: ")) fahrenheit = (9 / 5) * celsius + 32 print(celsius, "Celsius is", fahrenheit, "Fahrenheit") # 2.2 radius, length = eval(input("Enter area and volume: ")) area = radius * radius * 3.14 volume = area * length print("The area is", area) print("The volume is", volume) # 2.

item.title: Final
item.description: Final Review # SÌ·Ì¿ÌÍ’ÌŒÌÍ€ÍÌ›Ì€Ì„Ì…Í—ÌÌ½Í˜Í’ÌŠÍ—ÌŒÌ†Ì‘ÌÌŠÍÍ„Í›Í€ÍÍ‹Í„Ì’Í€Ì¾ÌšÌ“Ì„Ì•Ì¾ÌŠÌ½ÍÌ‡Ì‡Ì‚Ì”Í‹ÍÌ„Í‚ÌšÌÍŒÌ“ÍÌÍ‘Í‘ÌŒÌ…ÌƒÌ“ÌÍÍÍ‘Ì‡ÌœÌ®Ì©Ì—ÌœÌ Ì¦ÌªÌ®Í‰Ì©Ì«Í“Ì¼Í–Í™Ì©ÍÍšÍ…ÍšÍ…Ì©ÌÌ©Í“Ì²ÌÍ•Ì¹Ì Í–Ì«Ì°ÌœÌÍÍ™ÍÌ—ÌŸÌÌ¡Ì²Ì¨Í•Í…Ì¤ÍœÌ±Ì©Ì¯Í‰ÌŸÌ¨Ì¬ÍÌ™Ì™Í” Ì´Í’Í„ÌÌÌÌÍŠÌ¾Í†Ì“Í„Ì›ÌÌ“Í‚Ì¾Ì•ÌÌÌ‰Ì„Í—Ì‚Í’Ì‹ÌƒÌÌ‹ÍÍŒÍ‹Ì€ÌŠÌÍ‚Ì…ÌÍ†Í˜Í ÌšÍ†Ì’Ì‘ÍŠÌˆÌÌ‘ÍÍ‹ÌÌšÌ’Í„Ì½Ì¾Ì‚Ì¾Ì€Í˜ÌÌ”Ì‡ÍÌŠÍ Ì‚Ì“ÌƒÍ„Ì€Í„Ì’Í—Ì‰Ì†Ì…ÍŒÌ£Ì°Ì­Ì¬Ì±ÌÍˆÌ£Í‡Í™Í–ÌºÌ¥Ì±Ì¯Ì¼Í•Í‡Í•ÌŸÍ‡Ì©Ì˜Í…Ì¹ÌŸÍ”Ì¯Ì²ÍšÌ£Ì²Í“Í™ÍÌŸÌªÌªÌ®ÌÌŸÌ©ÌÌ§Ì¯Ì–Ì–Ì³Ì—ÍˆÌ¤Ì˜Ì¨Ì°Ì¯OÌ´ÍÌŒÍÍ†Í‚ÌˆÍÍÌ›ÌÌŒÌ¿ÍŠÌÍ‘Ì‡ÌŒÍ›Ì•ÍÌ†Ì¨Ì¡Í“Ì£Ì»Í‰ÍÍÍšÌ¼Í™Ì¦Í™Ì»ÌºÌ°Íœ ÌµÍƒÌ‹ÌÌ‘Ì¾ÍÍ›ÍŒÍ‚ÌÍ Ì‹Ì‹Ì…Í—Í€ÌÌ…Ì…ÍŠÌÌƒÍ˜Ì…Ì€Ì’ÍÌˆÌšÍ›Ì…Ì¦Ì²Ì¤ÌªÌ™Ì»Ì³ÍšÌ¦Ì Ì»Ì³Ì©Í‡Ì˜OÌ¸Ì•Ì›Ì‰Í‹Í‹Ì‘Ì„Í€ÌŒÌ…ÍÌ†ÌƒÌÌ…Ì”Ì‰ÍŠÍ˜Í‹Ì“Ì¾ÌŒÍƒÍŒÌ„Ì€Ì“Í‚Í„Ì¤ÍœÌœÌªÌ¯Ì¤ÌœÍ‡ÌŸÌ«Í™ÌÌ²ÍÍ‡Ì¡Í–Ì˜Ì¯Ì°ÍÌ¤Í–ÍœÍÌ–Ì–Ì­ÍˆÌ£Ì²Ì£ÌºÌºÍ“Ì¨Ì¨ÌœÌ²Ì®Ì¬ÍœÌÌ£Ì³Í™Í ÌµÌÌÌŠÌ€ÌŒÌ„Ì€ÍŒÍ„ÍÍ‹Ì¿Ì‰ÌŠÌÌ¿ÍƒÍ†Í‘ÌÌ¿Í„Í„ÌšÌ¡Ì«Ì˜Ì»Ì­Ì£Ì¢Ì¤ÌÍšÌŸÌ¤ÌŸÌ³Í–ÍœÌŸÌ®Ì¨Ì§Ì£Ì¦Ì™Í…ÌŸÌºÌ¼ÍˆÍœÌ¢Ì¯ÍšÌ¢Ì¬Ì³Ì©Ì˜Ì–Í”Ì¡ÌªÌ¡ÌºÌ©Í•ÍˆÍ‡ÍÌ¹Ì™Ì­Ì¤Í‰Ì±Ì¹Ì±Ì ÌŸÌ³Ì±Ì¦Ì¼NÌ´Ì½Ì‰Ì‡Ì†Ì¿ÌÌÍÌšÌÍ’Ì‚Ì’Í‘Ì½Ì„Ì‘ÍÍŠÍŠÌÌÌÌ”Í˜ÌÌˆÌ•ÍƒÌ‰ÍŠÍ‘Í€Ì†Í—ÌƒÍ€ÍÌšÌŒÌŠÍ€Ì¿Ì’Ì¾Í ÌšÍƒÌ”Ì‹ÌÌ¯ÌÌ±Ì­Ì¬Ì®ÍœÌ¬Ì­Ì—Ì­Ì¬Ì­Ì±Ì«Í‰Ì³Í‰ÌŸÌ±Ì Ì¢Í‡Ì±ÌºÌºÌ§ÍÍÌ—Ì–ÍˆÌ¢ÌŸÌ¥Ì¬Ì˜Ì–Ì¢ÍÌ®Ì±Í…ÍˆÍ–Ì¼Ì—Ì±Ì–Ì¤ÍˆÍ“Í•Ì Ì±Ì¦Ì˜ÌÍ“Ì ÌœÍœÌ¹Í‡Í“Ì Ì¹Í“Ì¹Í™Ì£Ì¼ÍÍ…

item.title: Style
item.description: Python Style Guide for CS 303E # Highlights # The following are highlighted style guidelines to follow based off the assignment page here. Two Blank Lines # This highlight states to include two blank lines both before and after our function: # ... # Grader: Skyler # # On my honor, Skyler Vestal, this programming assignment is my own work # and I have not provided this code to any other student.

item.title: Chapter 3
item.description: Chapter 3 Exercise Solutions # Download Solutions Embedded solutions: # Exercises for Chapter 3 of "Introduction to Programming using Python" # Solutions made by Skyler Vestal (Hook 'Em) import math import time # 3.2 length = eval(input("Enter the length from the center to a vertex: ")) side = 2 * length * math.sin(math.pi / 5) area = (3 * math.sqrt(3)/2) * side**2 print("The area of the pentagon is", round(area, 2)) # 3.

item.title: Chapter 4
item.description: Chapter 4 Exercise Solutions # Download Solutions Embedded solutions: # Exercies for Chapter 4 of "Introduction to Programming using Python" # Solutions made by Skyler Vestal (Hook 'Em) import math import random # 4.1 a, b, c = eval(input("Enter, a, b, c: ")) discrim = b ** 2 - (4 * a * c) if discrim < 0: print("The equation has no real roots") else: root_1 = (-b + math.

item.title: Chapter 5
item.description: Chapter 5 Exercise Solutions # Download Solutions Embedded solutions: # Exercises for Chapter 5 of "Introduction to Programming using Python" # Solutions made by Skyler Vestal (Hook 'Em) import math # 5.1 input_prompt = "Enter an integer, the input ends if it is 0: " keep_running = eval(input(input_prompt)) != 0 while keep_running: keep_running = eval(input(input_prompt)) != 0 # 5.3 print("Kilograms Pounds") for kilos in range(1, 200): pounds = kilos * 2.

item.title: Chapter 6
item.description: Chapter 6 Exercise Solutions # Download Solutions Embedded solutions: # Exercises for Chapter 6 of "Introduction to Programming using Python" # Solutions made by Skyler Vestal (Hook 'Em) import random # 6.1 # CS 311 exercise =) - Prove that for any n the pentagonal number # is an integer def getPentagonalNumber(n): return n * (3 * n - 1) // 2 for i in range(10): line_str = str(getPentagonalNumber(i * 10 + 1)) for j in range(2, 11): line_str += ", " + str(getPentagonalNumber(i * 10 + j)) print(line_str) # 6.

item.title: Chapter 7
item.description: Chapter 7 Exercise Solutions # Download Solutions Embedded solutions: # Exercises for Chapter 7 of "Introduction to Programming using Python" # Solutions made by Skyler Vestal (Hook 'Em) import time # 7.1 class Rectangle: def __init__(self, width = 1, height = 2): self.width = width self.height = height # Don't name functions like this at home kids def getArea(self): return self.width * self.height def getPerimeter(self): return 2 * (self.width + self.

item.title: Chapter 8
item.description: Chapter 8 Exercise Solutions # Download Solutions Embedded solutions: # Exercises for Chapter 8 of "Introduction to Programming using Python" # Solutions made by Skyler Vestal (Hook 'Em) # 8.1 # Look up Regular Expressions to see how string checks are normally done =) ssn = input("Enter a Social Security number: ") ssn_valid = True ssn_valid = len(ssn) == 11 index = 0 while ssn_valid and index < len(ssn): if index == 3 or index == 6: ssn_valid = ssn[index] == '-' else: ssn_valid = ssn[index].

item.title: Chapter 10
item.description: Chapter 10 Exercise Solutions # Download Solutions Embedded solutions: # Exercises for Chapter 10 of "Introduction to Programming using Python" # Solutions made by Skyler Vestal (Hook 'Em) import random # 10.2 # Not sure what format this question wants ... n = int(input("Enter the quantity of #s you'd like to enter: ")) num_list = [] for i in range(n): num_list.append(int(input("Enter a number: "))) num_list.reverse() print("Your numbers reversed:", num_list) # 10.

item.title: Chapter 11
item.description: Chapter 11 Exercise Solutions # Download Solutions Embedded solutions: # Exercises for Chapter 11 of "Introduction to Programming using Python" # Solutions made by Skyler Vestal (Hook 'Em) import math import random # 11.1 def sumColumn(m, columnIndex): mat_sum = 0 for i in range(len(m)): mat_sum += m[i][columnIndex] return mat_sum matrix = [] for i in range(3): user_input = input("Enter a 3-by-4 matrix row for row " + str(i) + ": ") row = [eval(x) for x in user_input.

item.title: Chapter 13
item.description: Chapter 13 Exercise Solutions # Download Solutions Embedded solutions: # Exercises for Chapter 13 of "Introduction to Programming using Python" # Solutions made by Skyler Vestal (Hook 'Em) # 13.1 # Could use r+ instead to read and write but book doesn't cover that >_> file_name = input("Enter a filename: ") f = open(file_name, "r") lines = f.readlines() lines = [x.replace("morning", "") for x in lines] f.close() # Book didn't cover writelines file UGH.
